title: Trust in the LORD
shortSummary: Psalm 115 emphasizes giving glory to God alone rather than to human efforts or idols. It contrasts the living God who reigns in heaven with the powerless idols made by men, calling Israel and all who fear the LORD to trust Him as their help and shield.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - United Monarchy period, attributed to the time of King David

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation of God's chosen people, called to trust in the LORD rather than idols.

keyCharacters.name: House of Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The priestly family descended from Aaron, called to rely on God’s help and protection.

keyCharacters.name: The Heathen
keyCharacters.description: The nations or peoples who mock Israel’s God, questioning His existence or power.

definitions.definition: A term used in the Bible to describe nations or peoples who do not worship the true God.
Physical objects made by human hands that are worshiped falsely as gods but are powerless.
A metaphor for God’s protection and defense over His people.
A reverent awe and respect for God that leads to obedience and trust.

outline.heading: Glory to God Alone
outline.description: The psalm opens by declaring that all glory belongs to God, not to humans, because of His mercy and truth. It affirms God’s sovereign rule from heaven and His freedom to act according to His will.

outline.heading: The Futility of Idols
outline.description: A vivid description of idols made of silver and gold that cannot speak, see, hear, or move, highlighting their impotence. Those who make and trust in idols are likened to them, emphasizing the folly of idolatry.

outline.heading: Call to Trust in the LORD
outline.description: A direct exhortation to Israel, the house of Aaron, and all who fear the LORD to place their trust in Him as their help and shield.

outline.heading: God’s Blessing on His People
outline.description: God’s remembrance leads to blessing for Israel, the priests, and all who fear Him. The LORD is recognized as Creator of heaven and earth, with the earth given to mankind.

outline.heading: Praise from the Living
outline.description: The psalm concludes by contrasting the dead, who cannot praise God, with the living who will bless and praise the LORD forever.

application: Give all glory and credit to God in your daily life, recognizing His mercy and truth rather than your own achievements.
Reject all forms of idolatry by examining what you trust in and ensuring it is the living God alone.
Place your full trust in God as your protector and helper, especially in times of difficulty or uncertainty.
Commit to praising and blessing the LORD continually, acknowledging His sovereignty and faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: Not unto us, O LORD, not unto us, but unto thy name give glory, for thy mercy, and for thy truth's sake.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the entire psalm, emphasizing that all glory belongs to God alone.

keyVerses.text: They that make them are like unto them; so is every one that trusteth in them.
keyVerses.significance: It warns that trusting in idols makes a person as powerless and ineffective as the idols themselves.

keyVerses.text: O Israel, trust thou in the LORD: he is their help and their shield.
keyVerses.significance: A clear call for God’s people to rely on Him for protection and assistance.

keyVerses.text: But we will bless the LORD from this time forth and for evermore. Praise the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: A commitment to lifelong praise and worship of God, highlighting the response of the living to God’s goodness.
